activities.title: HTTP Status Code Roulette
activities.desc: Call 10 real public APIs with bad inputs. Log the status codes returned. Vote on which ones are correct, misleading, or lazy.

activities.title: Error Handling Framework Design
activities.desc: Design a global error handler: map exceptions to HTTP codes, define error response schema, and handle validation vs business vs infra errors differently.

activities.title: Rate Limiting Algorithm Comparison
activities.desc: Implement token bucket and leaky bucket on paper for the same traffic pattern. Compare burst behavior and smoothness.

activities.title: API Design Audit
activities.desc: Review a provided REST API spec. Identify: missing validation, wrong status codes, unclear error messages, and security gaps.

concepts.heading: What it is
concepts.body: API Layer & Error Handling covers the design decisions needed to build reliable systems and explain those decisions in interviews. The core focus is understanding REST endpoints, Input validation, Rate limiting and linking each concept to an architecture consequence.

concepts.heading: Why it matters in interviews
concepts.body: Interviewers expect you to justify trade-offs, not just list tools. For API Layer & Error Handling, strong answers connect constraints, architecture choices, and failure behavior while staying explicit about what you would de-scope first.

flowSteps: Clarify scope and constraints for API Layer & Error Handling before choosing architecture primitives.
Define boundaries for REST endpoints and map request/write paths.
Introduce resilience points such as retries, idempotency, and observability checkpoints.
Evaluate bottlenecks under peak load or feature expansion assumptions.
Capture final trade-offs and explain why rejected alternatives were not selected.

tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Use composition by default in API Layer & Error Handling; use inheritance only for stable is-a relationships.
tradeoffs.risk: Deep hierarchies are brittle and hard to evolve.

tradeoffs.optionB: Direct implementation optimized for current scope
tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Invest in extensibility if frequent feature variants are expected; keep it direct for short-lived or fixed-scope components.
tradeoffs.risk: Over-abstraction slows delivery; under-abstraction creates future rewrite cost.

tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Use strict layering for larger teams and long-lived systems; allow shortcuts for isolated utility flows.
tradeoffs.risk: Shortcuts can spread and weaken boundaries if not governed.

tradeoffs.chooseWhen: Use strategy plugins for high variation domains; use static paths when behavior is stable.
tradeoffs.risk: Highly dynamic systems can be harder to debug and reason about.

examples.name: Public API Gateway
examples.context: Public API Gateway demands clear boundaries around REST endpoints and predictable behavior during peak usage.
examples.designChoice: Use a staged design with a fast path and a durable path, then expose explicit fallback behavior to callers.
examples.why: This keeps latency stable for normal traffic while preserving correctness for critical writes and failure recovery.

examples.name: Rate-Limited Billing API
examples.context: Rate-Limited Billing API introduces changing requirements and forces design updates without breaking existing clients.
examples.designChoice: Introduce stable interfaces, versioned contracts, and observability from the start so changes remain testable.
examples.why: You can iterate safely while preserving backward compatibility and maintaining confidence in production behavior.

cheatSheet: Start every API Layer & Error Handling answer with assumptions and limits.
Name one latency-sensitive path and one correctness-sensitive path.
State how REST endpoints is written and read under load.
Explain one scaling strategy and one fallback strategy.
Mention observability: metrics, logs, and tracing checkpoints.
Call out a deliberate de-scope to keep MVP practical.
Finish with what you would improve in version two.
redFlags: Choosing technology without linking it to constraints.
Ignoring data consistency or idempotency for write operations.
No failure-mode story for dependency outages.
No plan to measure whether the design is actually working.
